articles.title: Black Box Study
articles.description: Some details about the Black Box study data set
articles.contents:
Variables
The Black Box data set is used and discussed in the paper titled Accuracy and reliability of forensic latent fingerprint decisions by Bradford T. Ulery, et. al. The data is freely available online. It contains the examiners’ answers to the proficiency test questions. \(169\) examiners responded to approximately \(100\) presentations each of image pairs yielding \(17,121\) sets of responses. There are \(8\) variables total in this data set.
Examiner_ID: unique, anonymized identifier for the examiner
169 distinct values, ex: A5104
Pair_ID: unique identifier for the image pair
744 distinct values, ex: N057413
Mating: whether the latent and exemplar originate from the same source
ex: Mates, Non-mates
Latent_Value: examiner’s latent value decision
ex: NV, VID, VEO
Compare_Value: examiner’s comparison decision
ex: Exclusion, Individualization, Inconclusive, NA
Inconclusive_Reason: examiner’s reason for inconclusive decision
ex: Close, Insufficient, Overlap, NA
Exclusion_Reason: examiner’s reason for exclusion decision
ex: Minutiae, Pattern, NA
Difficulty: examiner’s rating of difficulty to make comparison decision
ex: A_Obvious, B_Easy, C_Medium, D_Difficult, E_VeryDifficult, NA
Data Set

articles.title: Welcome
articles.description: Welcome to the website. I hope you enjoy it!
articles.contents: The project is to develop Item Response Theory-based models for forensic proficiency testing. Item Response Theory is the class of models used to calculate student scores when they sit for different versions of the same exam (e.g. SAT and ACT). The basic idea is that we model the probability of a correct response as a function of both participant proficiency AND item difficulty, which are estimated from the data, which is closely related to logistic regression.

articles.title: Repeatability
articles.description: Some details about the Test and Retest data set
articles.contents:
The Repeatability and Reproducibility paper discusses and analyzes the data set discussed here. This study looks at the repeatability and reproducibility rate of prints. Repeatability is defined as whether one examiner consistently reaches the same decision on the same fingerprints, and reproducibility is defined as whether two examiners reach the same decision on the same fingerprints. The data is stored in a text file, and the variables and data set is displayed below.
Variables
Dataset: When picking prints for the user, each examiner receives \(25\) pairs to examine. Within these \(25\) pairs, \(9\) were non-mated image pairs and \(16\) were image pairs. Within the non-mated image pairs, examiners who had committed a false positive error previously (in the Black Box study) were reassigned that image (\(\text{FalsePos}\)), and the remaining are selected at random (\(\text{RandomNonMates}\)). Within the image pairs, \(11\) image pairs were selected at random out of the pairs that the examiner had not committed false negative errors (\(\text{RandomMates}\)), up to \(5\) image pairs where the examiners had committed false negative errors (\(\text{FalseNeg}\)), and the remaining pairs are randomly selected out of the pairs where the examiner also did not commit false negative errors (\(\text{ExtraMates}\)).
ex: \(\text{RandomMates}\), \(\text{FalseNeg}\), \(\text{ExtraMates}\), \(\text{RandomNonMates}\), \(\text{FalsePos}\)
Examiner_ID: unique, anonymized identifier for the examiner
ex: \(A2002\)
Pair_ID: unique identifier for the image pair
ex: \(M003061\)
Latent_ID: unique identifier for the latent print
ex: \(\text{L_003}\)
Exemplar_ID: unique identifier for the exemplar print
ex: \(\text{E_061}\)
Mating: whether the latent and exemplar originate from the same source
ex: \(\text{Mates}\), \(\text{Non-mates}\)
LatentRetest:
ex: \(\text{LatentRetest}\), \(\text{Ignore}\)
LV_Initial: initial latent print value
ex: VID, VEO, NV
LV_Retest: retest latent print value
ex: VID, VEO, NV
Comp_Initial: initial comparison determination
ex: \(\text{Inconclusive}\), \(\text{Individualization}\), \(\text{Exclusion}\), \(\text{Latent No Value}\)
Comp_Retest: retest comparison determination
ex: \(\text{Inconclusive}\), \(\text{Individualization}\), \(\text{Exclusion}\), \(\text{Latent No Value}\)
Excl_Initial: initial exclusion reason
ex: \(\text{MIN}\), \(\text{PAT}\), NA
Excl_Retest: retest exclusion reason
ex: \(\text{MIN}\), \(\text{PAT}\), NA
Inconc_Initial: initial inconclusive reason
ex: \(\text{Close}\), \(\text{Overlap}\), \(\text{Insufficient}\), NA
Inconc_Retest: retest inconclusive reason
ex: \(\text{Close}\), \(\text{Overlap}\), \(\text{Insufficient}\), NA
Difficulty_Initial: initial difficulty rating
ex: \(\text{A_Obvious}\), \(\text{B_Easy}\), \(\text{C_Medium}\), \(\text{D_Difficult}\), \(\text{E_VeryDifficult}\), NA
Difficulty_Retest: retest difficulty rating
ex: \(\text{A_Obvious}\), \(\text{B_Easy}\), \(\text{C_Medium}\), \(\text{D_Difficult}\), \(\text{E_VeryDifficult}\), NA

Same Pair Comparison
The graph below shows the minutiae mappings of the latent print M010003, across many examiners. The complete black dots show the (x, y) coordinates that examiners marked on the latent print during the analysis stage, and the slightly transparent points show the (x, y) coordinates that examiners marked on the latent print during the comparison stage. The lines indicate movements of the minutiae markings done by examiners between the analysis and comparison stages. The hex shapes show the density of clusters of points in the comparison stage; darker hexes show a larger cluster of points and lighter hexes show a smaller cluster of points.
ggplot(data = m010003_ac) +
  geom_hex(aes(x = x_comparison, y = y_comparison, alpha = log(..count..)),
           bins = 20, fill = "#000000") +
  geom_point(aes(x = x_analysis, y = y_analysis), alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_point(aes(x = x_comparison, y = y_comparison)) +
  geom_segment(aes(x = x_analysis, y = y_analysis, xend = x_comparison,
                   yend = y_comparison), alpha = 0.5) +
  my_theme +
  scale_color_grey() +
  labs(title = "Pair M010003: Analysis Evaluation", subtitle = "Sherry Huang, July 2021",
       x = "x", y = "y", color = "Analysis Type")

## Warning: Removed 13 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

## Warning: Removed 19 rows containing missing values (geom_segment).

       subtitle = "Sherry Huang, July 2021",
       x = "clarity (comparison)", y = "minutiae movement distance") +
  theme(legend.position = 'none')
## Warning: Removed 1992 rows containing missing values (position_stack).

ggplot(data = wb_analysiscomparison) +
  geom_col(aes(x = median_clarity_analysis, y = min_distance,
               color = median_clarity_analysis)) +
  my_theme +
  labs(title = "Median Clarity (Analysis) and Minutiae Movement",
       subtitle = "Sherry Huang, July 2021",
       x = "median clarity (analysis)", y = "minutiae movement distance") +
  theme(legend.position = 'none')
## Warning: Removed 7959 rows containing missing values (position_stack).

ggplot(data = wb_analysiscomparison) +
  geom_col(aes(x = median_clarity_comparison, y = min_distance,
               color = median_clarity_comparison)) +
  my_theme +
  labs(title = "Median Clarity (Comparison) and Minutiae Movement",
       subtitle = "Sherry Huang, July 2021",
       x = "median clarity (comparison)", y = "minutiae movement distance") +
  theme(legend.position = 'none')
## Warning: Removed 4929 rows containing missing values (position_stack).

ggplot(data = wb_analysiscomparison) +
  geom_col(aes(x = clarity_corresponding, y = min_distance,
               color = clarity_corresponding)) +
  my_theme +
  labs(title = "Clarity (Corresponding) and Minutiae Movement",
       subtitle = "Sherry Huang, July 2021",
       x = "clarity (corresponding)", y = "minutiae movement distance") +
  theme(legend.position = 'none')
## Warning: Removed 22771 rows containing missing values (position_stack).

wb_ac <- wb_analysiscomparison %>%
  mutate(clarity_change = case_when(
    clarity_analysis != clarity_comparison ~ "1",
    clarity_analysis == clarity_comparison ~ "0"))
ggplot(data = wb_ac) +
  geom_tile(aes(x = clarity_analysis, y = clarity_comparison, fill = min_distance)) +
  my_theme +
  labs(title = "Map of Minutiae Movement Distance and Clarity from Analysis to Comparison Stages",
       subtitle = "Sherry Huang, July 2021",
       x = "clarity (analysis)", y = "clarity (comparison)",
       fill = "minutiae\nmovement\ndistance")
## Warning: Removed 1992 rows containing missing values (geom_tile).

ggplot(data = wb_ac) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = min_distance, fill = clarity_change)) +
  my_theme +
  labs(title = "Distance vs Clarity Change", subtitle = "Sherry Huang, July 2021",
       x = "minutiae movement distance", fill = "change in clarity")

articles.title: White Box Study
articles.description: Some details about the White Box study data set
articles.contents:
The White Box study paper (and this additional paper about it) discusses and analyzes the White Box data set. The data is stored in an Excel sheet, and there are \(8\) tabs in it. Those different tabs are the data sets shown below.
WhiteBox_Survey
Variables
4.0: gender of examiner
ex: Female, Male
2. Age: age range of examiner
ex: \(30-39\), \(40-49\)
3. Education: education level of examiner
ex: Grad, Assoc, Bachelor, HS
4. Employer: employer of examiner
ex: U.S. City/County government, Non-U.S. National/Federal government, U.S. State government, U.S. Federal government
5. Agency accred.: whether examiner is accredited by agency
ex: Yes, No
6. Years employed: range of years examiner was employed
ex: \(5-9\), \(10-19\)
7. Training: examiners’ form of training
ex: Limited formal, Formal halfYear, Formal yr+, Other
8. IAI-cert:
ex: IAI, NA
8. Employer-cert:
ex: Employer, NA
8. National-cert:
ex: National, NA
8. Other-cert:
ex: Other, NA
9. Active:
ex: Yes, previously regular, No
10. Time spent:
ex: \(\text{Less than }10\%\), \(10-25\%\), \(25-50\%\), \(50-75\%\), \(75-100\%\)
11. Computer-based:
ex: \(0\% \text{ computer}\), \(1-30\% \text{ computer}\), \(30-60\% \text{ computer}\), \(60-99\% \text{ computer}\), \(100\% \text{ computer}\)
12. Single exemplar:
ex: \(\text{None}\), \(\text{Less than } 10\%\), \(10-25\%\), \(25-50\%\), \(50-75\%\), \(75-100\%\)
13. Limited match:
ex: Yes, No
14. VEOs:
ex: \(\text{its own category (standard)}\), \(\text{its own category (request)}\), \(\text{Of value}\), \(\text{No value}\)
15. AFIS value:
ex: \(\text{Yes, used as formal designation}\), \(\text{Yes, used informally}\), \(\text{No}\)
16. Test latents similar?:
ex: \(\text{Some of them}\), \(\text{Most of them}\), \(\text{All of them}\)
17. Exemplars similar?:
ex: \(\text{Some of them}\), \(\text{Most of them}\), \(\text{All of them}\), \(\text{All but one or two}\)
18. Compare to casework:
ex: \(\text{MUCH EASIER than casework}\), \(\text{EASIER than casework}\), \(\text{SIMILAR to casework}\), \(\text{HARDER than casework}\), \(\text{MUCH HARDER than casework}\)
19. Markup useful?:
ex: \(\text{Possibly}\), \(\text{Yes, for general practice}\), \(\text{Yes, Only for complex cases}\), \(\text{No}\)
20. PointStandardCount:
ex: \(16\), NA
